FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES

BHJ USA, LLC. We're a full service provider/processor supplying a broad spectrum of species specific proteins including beef, pork, organic and natural chicken, turkey, duck, salmon and white fish blends, formulated to client specifications, grind requirements, and delivered either frozen or in a fresh bulk pump ready form. Ammonia is used as a refrigerant to maintain freezing temperatures in the various stages of the process. 



The facility has two separate ammonia systems.  The refrigeration systems exceed the 10,000-pound threshold required for our production process and necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICY

It is the policy of BHJ USA, LLC to conduct business in a manner that is safe to the employees, the community, and the environment. The company's officers, managers, and supervisors are accountable to carry out the policies of the company relevant to the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous materials. Protein, Inc. has made a determined effort to develop a plan to prevent releases of extremely hazardous substances. Procedures to assist in the prevention of extremely hazardous material releases are set forth in EPA's Risk Management Program. In the event of a release, the Emergency Response Plan will be the guidance for responding to, containing and reporting such releases.  The Response Plan includes an incident command system for decision making authority for each stage of a release situation.  The company will coordinate with public responders and emergency services in ensuring safety of the public.



WORST AND ALTERNATE CASE DESCRIPTION

The worst case scenario is of a vessel being ruptured by a forklift or other form of impact.  The alternate case scenario is a pipe rupture on the outlet of an ammonia pump, this could be caused by a forklift or other form of impact.



RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

BHJ USA, LLC

has set forth in its policies the importance of operating safely.  The company has aggressively developed programs, policies and materials requirements to minimize the possibility of releases. These programs include compliance with appropriate OSHA and EPA regulations and sound safety practices. Stringent material and contractor requirements have been developed to assure that materials and work conform to recognized standards. Training for employees is conducted to maintain a high level awareness when working with hazardous materials.



Volume 1 of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates several policies. Many policies are included in Volume 1, the remaining are referenced from other training manuals maintained in the facility.



Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.



Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR ammonia Data Book).



Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.



Operating Procedures: develop, implement, and maintain clearly written, detailed procedures, guidelines, rules, and practices for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration process during all operating phases. The operating procedures provide all employees involved in the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration process with the written information and precautions necessary to safety perform their tasks in a consistent manner.



Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in t

he hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor.



Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been developed to monitor and provide a "checks and balances" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.



Mechanical Integrity Program: To prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of ammonia, it is important to ensure process equipment is maintained properly. The purpose of an MI program is to maintain process equipment so that a catastrophic release of ammonia is avoided or properly contained. The emphasis should be on preventive maintenance rather than breakdown maintenance.



Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, Employee training, etc.) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Operations Manager.



As part of the Prevention Program, Protein, Inc. has developed a method to evaluate the Risk Management Program. This method includes periodic evaluation of the Program utilizing a Process Hazard Analysis, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, and Compliance Audits.



Volume 2 incorporates information on the specific system components (Pumps, vessels, compressors, evaporators, evaporative condensers, purgers, piping systems, heat exchangers, the emergency ventilation system, and general safety). This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components. This manual also provides a checklist for performing the yearly Mechanical Integrity Inspection.



Volume 3 incorporates a complete valve list for each system. The valve list contains information on the type, port size, identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system.



Also included in Volume 3 is the Process and In

strumentation Diagrams for the individual system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire systems. A block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.



Volume 4 will incorporate a complete set of standard operating procedures, describing the proper steps for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation of system components, shutting down components as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pumpout procedures. Also included as a part of each Standard Operating Procedure is the Technical Operating Specifications for the associated system component. This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.



Volume 5 contains Operation and Maintenance Information including manufacturer's information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventive maintenance procedures.



PROCESS DESCRIPTION

BHJ USA, LLC Logansport, IN ammonia refrigeration systems are a standard compression and evaporation style system.  BHJ USA, LLC, is a food-based processing and distribution facility.

 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no RMP reportable accidents within the past five years. There have been small nuisance odors that have resulted in incident investigations.  



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Preparations for an emergency including, but not limited to: Fire, Release of hazardous chemicals including ammonia, Bomb Threat, Inclement weather, Civil Disorder, Hostile labor, Flood, Loss of water, Loss of electricity, Terrorist activities, Disruptions due to governmental inspections,

which may occur at this plant. Set-up an adequate chain of command during an emergency. Minimize the impact of an emergency on employee health and safety. Minimize the impact of an emergency on our neighbors and the environment. Follow-up emergency procedures. Our Program is coordinated with the Logansport Fire Department. 



SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS

Future changes to improve release prevention include: improved maintenance procedures, periodically; add new technology as it becomes available; and continued training of plant and response personnel. Our facility is constantly striving to "Lead the Field" in industrial safety. Our goal is and has been to be a responsible corporate citizen, protecting people and the environment. Our Program is continually reviewed (On a 18 month cycle) and updated as necessary.
